It is one of the two biggest priorities of the opening phase of chess, and can remain a priority throughout
the course of a game if pieces are left undeveloped for long enough.
In most openings, the following hierarchy is broadly observed:

items: Minor pieces (bishops and knights) are developed first. As these pieces are of lower

Additionally, it is necessary due to simple logistics to develop at least one knight and one
bishop before castling can be carried out.
The king is then castled out of the centre of the board and towards one of the corners, where it
is far easier to maintain a stronghold as threats can come from fewer possible directions, and
where conflict over central control cannot put the king at risk by proximity.
If opting to castle queenside, the queen must necessarily also be developed beforehand.
Castling can be purposefully deferred in favour of achieving other strategic goals, or even eschewed
entirely; however, taking either of these options without the requisite experience to recognise
when the position has become too dangerous to avoid castling any longer may lead to a swift loss.
is an additional possibility, and is often carried out as a fallback if standard castling has been
rendered impossible by the events of the game.

backward_pawns.title: Backward Pawns
description: A backward pawn is a pawn whose neighbouring pawns have advanced past it, meaning that it is the only pawn
amongst its neighbours which cannot be defended by another pawn in its current location.
Backward pawns are typically a
weakness; if they cannot be easily advanced, they must be guarded by pieces instead of by other pawns, which
necessitates tying those pieces down to their defence.
If a backward pawn is captured, its neighbouring pawns may also then become backward pawns as a consequence,

disintegrating as the weak spots multiply.
